intro: Haloragis scoparia, commonly known as the coastal wallaby grass, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of southern Australia. It is a perennial herb with slender, wiry stems that often grow along the ground or in low mounds. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers in dense clusters during the spring and summer months. It is adapted to sandy soils and can tolerate salt spray, making it a common species in coastal dunes and cliffs. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for native fauna and stabilizing coastal soils.
